text: When I look at this painting from Delaney,
one of the few queer black artists to rise to prominence,
I think about the way that he reclaimed,
kind of like this French modernism with the bowl of
fruit and really fucked it up in a way,
really queered it up in a way with this African kind of
sculpture that actually feels as if it's scaring off the crow in some way
like this is my fruit bitch.
There's something so hip hop about this too and I don't know if it's because I know it's from a black queer artist,
but there's something about the ways in which these different cultures and
elements and figures and objects are remixed and put together in this way.
You have something that's classic, like a classic beat, right?
With the fruit coming with something aggressive but also in nature like the crow.
And then you also have the presence of a black body in a sense, right?
Standing in with this figurine, this African figurine,
standing watch and maybe calling attention or screaming back at the crow in some way.
So it's like a clash of cultures in a really um beautiful and powerful and distinct way.
